awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Advancing first-principle symmetry-guided nuclear modeling for studies of nucleosynthesis and fundamental symmetries in nature
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding the origin, structure, and phases of hadronic matter is key to comprehending the evolution of the universe. To fully achieve this, we need to model the complex dynamics of atomic nuclei. The scale of computational challenges that are inherent to modeling such intricate quantum many-body systems makes the utilization of petascale level resources, like Blue Waters, essential. The objective of this project is to use the Blue Waters system to advance large-scale modeling of light through intermediate-mass nuclei and, for the first time, medium-mass nuclei, including short-lived isotopes not yet accessible to experiment but key to breakthrough solutions to open questions in basic and applied research, as well as the focus of next-generation radioactive beam facilities. 

Specifically, the project will use an innovative approach, the symmetry-adapted no-core shell model (SA-NCSM), which employs exact as well as approximate symmetries of nuclei to solve the nonrelativistic Schrodinger equation for a system of particles interacting via realistic nuclear forces. The proposed calculations will provide nuclear wave functions of unprecedented accuracy that are crucial for gaining further knowledge of fundamental symmetries in nature, as well as on extracting information from large datasets that is essential for neutrino physics, for probing physics beyond the standard model, and modeling of astrophysical processes.   

In addition, the project will train and educate graduate students and postdoctoral researchers in nuclear structure modeling using large-scale computational resources to address important problems in physics and related fields. The students will acquire and further their skills in the development of high performance computational physics software, laying the foundations for their careers in science and technology.  Moreover, the project will provide open access to software and data, including nuclear structure information of unprecedented accuracy and scope -- only possible when coupled with the Blue Waters computational capabilities -- as a publicly available database.

por.por_cntn:
Support of this proposal has enabled transformative research in low-energy nuclear science.  The combination of the ab initio symmetry-adapted no-core shell model (SA-NCSM) with the petascale computational power of the Blue Waters (BW) system has opened up an entire region of the periodic table, the intermediate-mass and medium-mass nuclei, to forefront research with ab initio theory that holds predictive capability. This has far-reaching implications beyond nuclear structure physics as well, namely, the outcomes of the project represent a first step toward achieving predictions for nuclei that are key to understanding nucleosynthesis and are of importance to neutrino research, and in turn, can help address two of the most fundamental questions of physics today: the origin of elements and if the neutrino is its own antiparticle. This research also involved graduate students and a postdoc who have acquired and furthered their skills in the development of high performance computational physics software, laying the foundations for their careers in science and technology, as they get prepared to become the next-generation "petascale-smart" researchers.

 

The Blue Waters (BW) system enables us to achieve large-scale modeling of light and medium-mass nuclei, including short-lived nuclei not yet accessible to experiment and nuclei key to understanding astrophysical processes to be studied at next-generation rare isotope experimental facilities.  In particular, the LSU team has developed and optimized codes for the use of a symplectic basis, for one-body densities, as well as an initial implementation to treat three-nucleon interactions, including the work on code optimization and the use of GPU's, in close collaboration with the team at Princeton U. (collaboration established as a part of a PAID award under a previous PRAC grant), along with Czech collaborators and the assistance of the BW project team.

 

New results are now available in the intermediate- and medium-mass nuclei, made possible by the combination of the ab initio SA-NCSM and the BW system. These include the first SA-NCSM calculations with chiral interactions, derived in the effective-field theory, of open-shell stable and short-lived nuclei up to the calcium region. We have studied the challenging phenomena of emergent deformation and clustering in the nuclei from first principles. First ab initio results have been provided for Mg isotopes and their mirror nuclei.

Nuclei in the intermediate-mass region are key to further understanding X-ray burst nucleosynthesis. Specifically, we have calculated reaction rates for alpha capture on O-16 (note that these solutions are feasible due to the ability of the SA-NCSM to trim the size of the model space to only the physically relevant basis states, e.g., down to tens of millions of basis states for the lowest 6+ state in Ne-20, as compared to the inaccessible full size of a trillion basis states). Reaction rates calculated from the SA-NCSM are, in turn, used to inform X-ray burst simulations, and may have a significant potential impact on nucleosynthesis studies.

We have also provided results for the very challenging nuclei of mass A=48. First-principle simulations of Ca-48 and Ti-48 in the SA-NCSM are now feasible and collective observables are found to closely agree with experiment. These nuclei are of importance to studies of neutrinoless double-beta decay. The goal is to reduce large uncertainties in the nuclear structure matrix elements, which will, in turn, allow one to determine from planned experiments if the neutrino is a Majorana or Dirac particle, which represents one of the most fundamental problems in physics today.

For neutrino experiments, it is important to reduce uncertainties related to the response of the detector nuclei to the neutrino. Response functions are now feasible for intermediate-mass nuclei, such as Ar-40, the next-generator detector ingredient. As an illustration, the BW has allowed us to carry forward large-scale ab initio calculations for the response for Ne-20, including the negative parity states. Such calculations are important for studies of nuclear compressibility, which in turn informs the equation of state for neutron stars. In addition, various peaks in the response function can provide further insight into clustering substructures and collective degrees of freedom.

Some 19 refereed publications (including a letter and two HPC/ computational physics articles), 2 conference proceedings, a book and a chapter in a book, in addition to 21 invited lectures have been produced under this award over its two-year period.  It also resulted in 18 talks or poster presentations of 1 LSU undergraduate students, 4 graduate students, and a postdoc, as well as a presentation of a graduate student at two Blue Waters symposia. Members of the collaboration have also attended scientific meetings where advanced applications of high-performance computers were reviewed and best practices were discussed. We have acquired knowledge of best practices for applications of hybrid computing, MPI/OpenMP, to forefront computational problems in nuclear structure. We have passed this knowledge on to students and postdocs in our groups.
